teamMembers.name: Austin Daniel

icp.title: The Growth-Obsessed Founder
icp.companyProfile: Seed to Series C SaaS/tech startups (5-50 employees)

connectCriteria: Founding CEO or technical co-founder at early-stage SaaS company
Posts about hiring engineers, building MVP, or scaling product
Raised seed/Series A in last 12 months (fundraising pressure = need for speed)
Mentions 'technical debt,' 'need to ship faster,' or 'team capacity' in posts
Active in communities like SaaStr, Pavilion, Y Combinator alumni
engageCriteria: Pre-revenue/pre-product (too early)
Posts about general startup advice (not specific pain)
Serial entrepreneurs but not actively building
Focus only on fundraising/networking content (not execution)
realQuotes: The building-as-procrastination trap is so real. I finally started doing customer calls when I made it a game.
I'd be a billionaire if my CTO and I could have gotten along better.
Behind every successful founder is paralyzing self-doubt, money issues, failed products.
The startup problem is fundamentally a search problem under resource constraint.
I realized most founders obsess over signups but ignore what happens in the first 3 minutes after someone logs in.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [specific challenge]. That's the exact problem we help founders solve at Midwestern. Curious—are you handling [specific task] internally or bringing in outside help?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about capacity/hiring challenges

conversationStarters.template: [Name], been following your journey with [company]. We work with a lot of founders at your stage (Series A, scaling eng team) and the 'need to ship vs. need to hire' tension is real. How are you thinking about that?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: After they've posted about team/scaling issues

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw you're [building X/hiring Y]. We've helped a bunch of startups like [similar company] navigate that exact phase. Happy to share what worked for them if you ever want to chat—no pitch, just founder to founder.
conversationStarters.whenToUse: Soft opener when relationship is warming up

contentPillars.title: Speed Wins Stories
contentPillars.description: Show how fast shipping creates competitive advantage
examples: Case study: How [startup] shipped their MVP in 6 weeks instead of 6 months
Behind-the-scenes: What a scoped project actually looks like [screenshots]
Data point: The average cost of a 6-month hiring delay
contentPillars.postingTips: Use specific timelines and metrics. Founders love numbers.

contentPillars.title: Founder Realities
contentPillars.description: Address the uncomfortable truths of founding
examples: Hot take: Stop hiring full-time engineers for MVP validation
Poll: What's slowing you down more: unclear requirements or team capacity?
Carousel: 5 signs you need embedded engineers, not full-time hires
contentPillars.postingTips: Be controversial but not offensive. Gets engagement through debate.

contentPillars.title: Transparent Process
contentPillars.description: Build trust through vulnerability and process sharing
examples: Here's our exact scoping process [step by step]
What it looks like to integrate into a client's Slack
We lost a client because [lesson learned]
contentPillars.postingTips: Vulnerability builds trust. Share mistakes, not just wins.

engagementBoosters.why: When founders check LinkedIn with coffee or during lunch break
Use 'Unpopular opinion:' or 'Hard truth:' or 'Quick story:' to grab attention
Triggers comments, which the algorithm loves

engagementBoosters.action: Comment on 5-10 founder posts BEFORE posting
engagementBoosters.why: Warms up the algorithm to show your content
Not spammy - only if they're actually mentioned (e.g., '@Jason Lemkin talked about this')

redFlags: Pre-idea stage (no product to build)
No funding/revenue signals (can't afford you)
Looking for 'co-founder' or 'equity partner' language
Non-technical founder with no CTO (they need recruiting first)
Focus is on 'thought leadership' not building (not your buyer)
trustBuilders: Peer validation: 'Who else have you worked with in [their space]?'
Portfolio proof: Case studies from similar stage/industry
Team credentials: They want to know the actual devs are legit
Speed guarantee: 'When can we start?' is often deal-closer
Direct references from other founders

quickReference.decisionSpeed: FAST (2-3 weeks if they trust you)
whenWarm: They've engaged with your content 3+ times
They ask questions about your work
They've shared their challenges without prompting

teamMembers.name: Austin Eidson

icp.title: The Design Leader Fighting for Influence
icp.companyProfile: Series A to growth-stage companies (50-500 employees)

connectCriteria: Design Director/Head of Design at growth-stage company
Posts about design systems, design debt, or scaling design teams
Mentions 'limited resources,' 'design maturity,' or 'proving ROI' in posts
Works at SaaS/tech companies (not agencies - wrong buyer)
Recently joined new role (building their team, open to partners)
engageCriteria: Individual contributor designers (not decision-makers)
Posts only about design trends/inspiration (not operational pain)
Works at design agencies (they're your competitors, not customers)
Focus on personal brand building (not team/company problems)
realQuotes: Design isn't done at visuals—it's done at behavior.
I'm tired of operating on 'gut-feeling' vs. research. We need data.
Our design system is 3 years old and held together with duct tape.
Every rebrand we do becomes outdated the moment we ship it.
Leadership treats design like a service org, not a strategic function.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [design system challenge]. We just wrapped a design system project for [similar company] and hit the exact same issues. How are you thinking about tackling it?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about design systems or technical design challenges

conversationStarters.template: [Name], curious question—when you get requests from product/marketing/sales for design work, what percentage can your team actually take on vs. what gets deprioritized?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention being overwhelmed or capacity issues

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], love how you talk about design maturity. We work with a lot of design leaders at your stage and the 'prove ROI vs. just ship beautiful work' tension is real. What's working for you?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: After they've discussed design's business impact

contentPillars.title: Design System Mastery
contentPillars.description: Position as experts in scalable design infrastructure
examples: Case study: How we built [company's] component library in 8 weeks
Process doc: Our design system handoff checklist [screenshot]
Hot take: Stop rebuilding your design system every 2 years
contentPillars.postingTips: Show actual work - screenshots of Figma, code examples. Visual proof.

contentPillars.title: Design Team Scaling
contentPillars.description: Help leaders solve the hiring vs. capacity problem
examples: Framework: When to hire vs. when to embed designers [decision tree]
Behind-scenes: What an embedded designer's first week looks like
Data: The real cost of design debt [calculate hours lost]
contentPillars.postingTips: Use frameworks and decision trees. Design leaders love structured thinking.

contentPillars.title: Proving Design Impact
contentPillars.description: Give them ammo for leadership conversations
examples: Metrics guide: How to tie design work to revenue/retention
Before/after: How design changes impacted [specific metric] for [client]
Interview: How [design leader] convinced their CEO to invest in design
contentPillars.postingTips: Always include numbers. Metrics make the business case.

engagementBoosters.why: Design leaders are visual people - screenshot, mockup, before/after
LinkedIn loves multi-image posts - more time on platform = more reach
Julie Zhuo, Cap Watkins - their audience is your audience
'What's your biggest design challenge: [A/B/C/D]?' gets easy engagement

engagementBoosters.action: Share work-in-progress not just finished work
engagementBoosters.why: Vulnerability = relatability. Show the messy middle.

redFlags: Solo designer (no budget authority)
Agency designer (they're not your customer)
Pure visual/brand designer (you do product design/systems)
Company has no design maturity (will be uphill battle)
Posts only about freelance work (not building a team)
trustBuilders: Portfolio work in similar industries (especially B2B SaaS)
Examples of explaining complex products simply
Case studies with metrics (not just 'pretty work')
Process explanation (not just deliverables)
Cost comparison vs. full-time hire

quickReference.buyingCommittee: VP Product or CPO (budget owner), sometimes CTO
whenWarm: They've saved/shared your design content
They ask about your process or team
They mention resource constraints unprompted

teamMembers.name: Cyril Jones

icp.title: The Technical Leader Who Needs to Ship Yesterday

connectCriteria: Technical founder/CTO at pre-Series B startup
Posts about 'building MVP,' 'need to ship,' or 'tech stack decisions'
Recently announced funding (have money, have pressure)
Mentions specific technologies you work with (React, Node, .NET, AI)
Asks questions about 'how to scope,' 'build vs. buy,' or 'finding developers'
engageCriteria: At large enterprises (different buying process)
Posts only about management/leadership (not hands-on technical)
Focus on recruiting only (might need recruiting service, not dev work)
Share only thought leadership (not actual building problems)
realQuotes: I need to build an MVP to get initial product to customers.
Has money but needs a team they can trust to execute.
Needs proper planning and documentation to justify spend.
How do I turn this idea into something real without blowing my budget on the wrong partner?
Lack of skill on internal team.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [MVP/feature scoping]. That's literally what we do all day at Midwestern - help founders break big ideas into shippable phases. Have you landed on an approach yet or still figuring it out?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about scoping challenges or unclear requirements

conversationStarters.template: [Name], curious about your [specific project] timeline. Most founders we work with underestimate builds by 2-3x. Are you working with a dev team already or exploring options?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention timelines or launch deadlines

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw you're considering [tech stack]. We've built [similar product] on that stack 5+ times. Happy to share what worked and what to avoid if helpful—no pitch, just founder to founder.
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they're evaluating tech decisions

contentPillars.title: Scoping Reality
contentPillars.description: Help founders understand what MVPs actually need
examples: Framework: How to scope an MVP in 1 hour [our exact process]
Case study: We helped [founder] cut scope from 6 months to 6 weeks
Hot take: Stop adding features to your MVP
contentPillars.postingTips: Be opinionated. Controversial takes get debates in comments.

contentPillars.title: Technical Transparency
contentPillars.description: Show your work to build credibility
examples: Behind-scenes: What a fixed-price project proposal looks like [redacted example]
Tech stack guide: When to use [React] vs. [Next.js] for [use case]
Mistake post: We over-scoped [project] and here's what we learned
contentPillars.postingTips: Show actual documents, proposals, code. Technical founders want proof.

contentPillars.title: Real Timelines
contentPillars.description: Set realistic expectations for build time
examples: Data: How long it ACTUALLY takes to build [common features]
Comparison: Building yourself vs. Scoped project vs. Embedded [cost/time analysis]
Poll: How long did your MVP take? [poll with ranges]
contentPillars.postingTips: Founders love specifics. Use actual numbers, not ranges.

engagementBoosters.why: React, Node, AWS triggers algorithm + attracts right people
'Hot take: Most MVPs are 3x too complex' gets debates in comments
Costs, timelines, team sizes - founders love specifics
'As we talk about at @Y Combinator' or 'Like @Indie Hackers discusses'
'Am I wrong about this?' or 'What's been your experience?' triggers engagement

redFlags: No clear product/customer (just an idea)
Looking for 'co-founder' or 'equity partner'
No funding and no revenue (can't pay)
Wants someone else to validate their idea (not ready)
Posts about 'the next big thing' but no execution updates
trustBuilders: Similar MVP builds you've done (case studies)
Clear scoping process (how do you prevent bloat?)
Team credentials (who's actually building this?)
Fixed pricing (they're terrified of runaway costs)
References from other technical founders

quickReference.decisionSpeed: FAST if urgent (1-2 weeks), MEDIUM if exploratory (4-6 weeks)
whenWarm: They ask technical questions about your process
They mention specific timelines or milestones
They've had bad experiences with other agencies

teamMembers.name: Dom Paulk

icp.title: The Execution Leader Stuck in Process Hell

connectCriteria: VP Product/Engineering at Series A+ company
Posts about 'roadmap challenges,' 'team velocity,' or 'cross-functional alignment'
Mentions 'not enough capacity,' 'too many priorities,' or 'shipping delays'
Works at B2B SaaS or tech companies (your sweet spot)
Recently changed jobs (building their team/processes)
engageCriteria: Director-level (might not have budget authority)
Posts only about frameworks/theory (not actual execution problems)
Works at agencies or consulting firms (wrong buyer)
Focus on thought leadership about 'the future of product' (not current pain)
realQuotes: PM workflows that actually scale.
Agile without the theater.
Keeping cross-functional teams aligned.
The hardest part: feeling like you're always failing.
People operating out of lane stresses everyone.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [roadmap/capacity challenge]. That's the exact problem we help solve - giving VPs execution capacity without the hiring timeline. Curious, how are you currently handling the gap between what's promised and what's realistic?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about roadmap pressure or capacity issues

conversationStarters.template: [Name], your post about [cross-functional alignment] hit home. Most VPs we work with spend more time coordinating than actually shipping. What's your current strategy for keeping teams aligned?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention team coordination or process problems

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], love how you think about [specific framework/process]. We work with a lot of product leaders at your stage and the 'ship fast vs. ship right' tension never goes away. What's been working for you lately?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: After they've shared process insights or frameworks

contentPillars.title: Execution at Scale
contentPillars.description: Help leaders prioritize and execute under pressure
examples: Framework: How to prioritize roadmap when everything is 'urgent' [our decision tree]
Case study: How [VP] shipped 5 features in one quarter with embedded team
Data: The real cost of context switching [calculate time lost per engineer]
contentPillars.postingTips: Use frameworks and decision trees. VPs love structured thinking.

contentPillars.title: Team Velocity
contentPillars.description: Show how to increase output without increasing headcount
examples: Process doc: How we integrate into client teams in week 1 [checklist]
Comparison: Hiring vs. Embedded vs. Freelancers [speed/cost/risk analysis]
Behind-scenes: What it looks like when embedded teams join your standups
contentPillars.postingTips: Show the actual integration process. VPs need to visualize how it works.

contentPillars.title: Transparent Failures
contentPillars.description: Build trust through vulnerability
examples: Mistake story: We under-scoped [project] and here's what we learned
Hot take: More engineers ≠ more output (and what actually works)
Interview: How [VP] doubled shipping velocity without hiring
contentPillars.postingTips: Vulnerability builds trust. Share what went wrong and why.

engagementBoosters.why: VPs love actionable frameworks (saves/shares = reach)
'Teams with X ship Y% faster' - VPs respond to metrics
Shreyas Doshi, Gibson Biddle, Lenny Rachitsky
'What's your biggest bottleneck? [capacity/clarity/alignment/tools]'
VPs read LinkedIn thoroughly (not just skimming) - 300+ words is fine

redFlags: No clear roadmap or priorities (too chaotic to help)
Company is pre-product or pivoting constantly (not stable enough)
Posts blame engineers/designers (toxic culture)
Every post is about tools/process (not actual execution)
Recently laid off team (cutting costs, not buying)
trustBuilders: Case studies from similar-stage companies
How we integrate into existing workflows (Jira, Confluence, Slack)
Team structure (who's the PM? Who's the tech lead?)
Metrics/KPIs to prove impact
Reference calls with other VPs

quickReference.buyingCommittee: VP Engineering, CTO or CPO (budget), sometimes CEO
whenWarm: They've shared specific roadmap challenges
They respond to questions about their process
They mention capacity gaps unprompted

teamMembers.name: Jerrod Tracy

icp.title: The Technical Leader Drowning in Legacy Debt

connectCriteria: VP Eng/CTO/Director IT at growth-stage or enterprise company
Posts about 'legacy systems,' 'tech debt,' or 'modernization'
Mentions specific old tech (.NET Framework, mainframes, PHP 5, Oracle)
Talks about 'slow delivery,' 'performance bottlenecks,' or 'DevOps mess'
Works at traditional industries going digital (manufacturing, finance, healthcare)
engageCriteria: At startups (too early for legacy debt)
Posts only about new tech trends (not dealing with legacy reality)
Works at pure tech companies (they have resources in-house)
Focus on architecture theory (not operational pain)
realQuotes: Legacy systems needing modernization.
Overwhelming technical debt.
Slow-to-launch timelines.
Application performance bottlenecks.
Why is DevOps still such a fragmented, exhausting mess in 2025?

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [specific legacy system]. We've migrated [similar old tech] to [modern equivalent] 5+ times. Curious - are you planning a full rewrite or incremental modernization?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention specific legacy technology

conversationStarters.template: [Name], your post about [technical debt] resonated. The hardest part is always convincing leadership it's worth it, right? How are you making the business case internally?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they discuss technical debt or modernization challenges

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], question about your [modernization project]. Most CTOs we work with can't pull people off core systems to rebuild. Have you considered a parallel build approach where modernization happens alongside maintenance?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they're stuck between maintaining and modernizing

contentPillars.title: Modernization Reality
contentPillars.description: Show how to migrate without breaking production
examples: Case study: How we migrated [company] from .NET Framework to .NET 8 with zero downtime
Framework: When to rewrite vs. refactor [decision matrix]
Data: The true cost of legacy systems [calculate opportunity cost]
contentPillars.postingTips: Be specific about tech stacks. Use before/after metrics.

contentPillars.title: Technical Debt Strategy
contentPillars.description: Give them a playbook for incremental improvement
examples: Process doc: How to tackle tech debt incrementally [step-by-step]
Hot take: Stop asking for permission to pay down tech debt
Comparison: Big bang rewrite vs. strangler pattern [risk analysis]
contentPillars.postingTips: CTOs need strategies, not just commiseration.

contentPillars.title: Infrastructure as Competitive Advantage
contentPillars.description: Show the business case for modernization
examples: Behind-scenes: What a greenfield project looks like while legacy runs
Interview: How [CTO] convinced the board to invest in modernization
Technical deep-dive: Migrating [specific system] - lessons learned
contentPillars.postingTips: Show ROI in business terms, not just technical benefits.

engagementBoosters.why: '.NET Framework 4.x to .NET 8' attracts right people
'We rescued a failed migration and here's what was wrong'
CTOs love seeing actual technical content
Your audience overlaps heavily with infrastructure folks
Technical leaders read carefully (1000+ words is fine for major topics)

redFlags: Startup or early-stage (no legacy debt yet)
Pure innovation focus, no maintenance burden (not your problem)
Posts only about cutting-edge tech (not dealing with legacy reality)
Recent layoffs or cost-cutting mode (frozen budgets)
Posts blame engineers for legacy debt (toxic, won't change)
trustBuilders: Legacy modernization case studies (specific: 'migrated Company X from...')
Team credentials (senior engineers who've done this 5+ times)
Risk mitigation plan (how do we not break production?)
Phased approach (not 'big bang' rewrites)
Reference calls with other VPs of Engineering

quickReference.buyingCommittee: CTO, Director/VP Infrastructure, sometimes CIO/CISO, CFO for major spend
whenWarm: They've shared specific legacy system challenges
They ask about your migration approach
They mention executive pressure to modernize

teamMembers.name: Jesse Kinzer

icp.title: The Lean Marketing Leader Doing 10 Jobs

connectCriteria: Director of Marketing at early/growth-stage company
Posts about 'limited resources,' 'design bottlenecks,' or 'content production'
Mentions 'standing out,' 'crowded market,' or 'explaining our product'
Works at B2B SaaS or technical companies (need to explain complex products)
Recently joined company (building their marketing function)
engageCriteria: At marketing agencies (they're competitors, not customers)
Posts only about marketing theory/trends (not operational challenges)
Works at consumer brands (different problems than B2B)
Focus on personal brand building as consultant (not in-house marketer)
realQuotes: Building marketing systems for lean teams (and when to embed vs. hire).
Motion design that explains complex products (SaaS, AI, technical offerings).
Need to stand out in crowded market.
Limited resources.
Doing too much themselves.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [standing out/differentiation]. We've helped a bunch of B2B marketers create explainer videos and brand assets that actually make prospects stop scrolling. What's your current approach to standing out visually?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about brand differentiation or standing out

conversationStarters.template: [Name], your post about [doing 10 jobs] hit home. Most marketing directors we work with are drowning in requests—product wants videos, sales wants collateral, CEO wants rebrand. How do you prioritize when everything's urgent?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention being overwhelmed or resource-constrained

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], curious question—how long does it take your sales team to explain what [your product] does? Most B2B marketers we work with struggle to explain technical products simply. What's working for you?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they discuss product marketing or sales enablement

contentPillars.title: Scrappy Marketing Wins
contentPillars.description: Show how to do enterprise marketing on startup budget

Budget breakdown: How we created [launch assets] for under $X
Hot take: Stop doing enterprise marketing on startup budget
contentPillars.postingTips: Show actual budgets and results. Marketers love seeing the math.

contentPillars.title: Creative Process Transparency
contentPillars.description: Build trust by showing how the sausage is made
examples: Behind-scenes: What our design process looks like [step-by-step with screenshots]
Before/after: How design changes impacted [metric] for [client]
Framework: When to hire vs. embed creative talent [decision tree]
contentPillars.postingTips: Always include visuals. Marketers want to see the work.

contentPillars.title: Explaining Complex Products
contentPillars.description: Position as experts in B2B product marketing
examples: Tutorial: How to create explainer videos that actually explain
Examples: 5 B2B brands that nail product clarity
Mistake story: We made [technical product] too simple and lost credibility
contentPillars.postingTips: Use examples. Show good vs. bad explanations side-by-side.

engagementBoosters.why: Marketers are visual - show don't tell
Before/afters, case studies, screenshots (proof not promises)
April Dunford, Peep Laja, Demand Curve
'Here's what $10k of design work actually looks like'
'Where does most of your time go? [content/design/strategy/reporting]'

redFlags: Marketing agency employee (competitor, not customer)
Consumer brand marketer (different problems)
Freelance consultant building personal brand (not in-house)
Enterprise marketer with big budgets/teams (not resource-constrained)
Posts only about LinkedIn growth/thought leadership (not operational)
trustBuilders: Portfolio work in similar industries (especially B2B SaaS)
Examples of explaining complex products simply
Case studies with metrics (not just pretty work)
Process explanation (not just deliverables)
Cost comparison vs. full-time hire

whenWarm: They've engaged with your creative content
They ask about your process or pricing
They share challenges without prompting

teamMembers.name: Ryan Doss

icp.title: The CTO Balancing Tech Decisions and Team Culture

connectCriteria: CTO at Series A to C company
Posts about 'tech stack decisions,' 'scaling teams,' or 'hiring challenges'
Mentions 'technical debt,' 'budget trade-offs,' or 'build vs. buy'
Shares specific tech they're working with (matches your capabilities)
Talks about wanting to 'test before hiring' or 'flexible capacity'
engageCriteria: At very large enterprises (different decision process)
Posts only about theory/thought leadership (not hands-on problems)
Works at agencies/consulting (not your customer)
Focus purely on recruiting (might need recruiting service only)
realQuotes: CTO budget decisions and trade-offs.
Scaling engineering teams without losing culture.
Tech stack decisions (when to adopt, when to wait).
Technical debt — when to pay it down, when to live with it.
Want to test engineers before full-time commitment.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [specific tech decision]. We've built production systems on [that stack] 5+ times. Curious what's making you lean toward [option A] vs [option B]?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they're evaluating tech stack choices

conversationStarters.template: [Name], your post about [hiring challenges] resonated. Most CTOs we work with wish they could test engineers for 3 months before committing. That's literally our embedded model—curious if that's something you've considered?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention hiring challenges or team scaling

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], question about your [scaling plans]. When you add engineers, are you looking for permanent headcount or would flexible capacity (scale up for launches, scale down between) make more sense?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they discuss team growth or capacity needs

contentPillars.title: Tech Stack Reality
contentPillars.description: Help CTOs make better technology bets
examples: Decision framework: How to choose tech stack in 2026 [our criteria]
Case study: Why [company] chose [stack] and what happened
Hot take: Stop choosing tech because it's trendy
contentPillars.postingTips: Be opinionated but data-driven. CTOs want reasoning, not hype.

contentPillars.title: Team Scaling Without Breaking Culture
contentPillars.description: Address the hardest part of CTO role
examples: Framework: How to scale from 10→50 engineers without losing velocity
Story: What breaks when you scale teams (and how to prevent it)
Data: The real cost of bad hires [calculate impact]
contentPillars.postingTips: Share both failures and wins. CTOs trust vulnerability.

contentPillars.title: The Embedded Model
contentPillars.description: Explain the 'test drive' approach
examples: Explainer: How 'try before you hire' actually works [step-by-step]
Comparison: Full-time vs. Embedded vs. Contractors [honest breakdown]
Behind-scenes: A day in the life of an embedded engineer
contentPillars.postingTips: Show the actual mechanics. CTOs need to understand how it works.

engagementBoosters.why: 'React vs. Vue in 2026' attracts technical audience
CTOs collect mental models
Charity Majors, Will Larson, Gergely Orosz
'What it actually costs to hire vs. embed'
CTOs read deeply, 800+ words is fine

redFlags: Looking for co-founder or equity partner (not buyer)
Pre-product or constantly pivoting (too unstable)
Posts about 'future of engineering' but no execution updates
Budget-cutting mode or recent layoffs (frozen spending)
Blame culture posts (will throw contractors under bus)
trustBuilders: Technical credentials (who are the actual engineers?)
Case studies in similar tech stacks
Team integration story (how do they join Slack, GitHub, standups?)
Cost comparison vs. full-time hires
Reference calls with other CTOs

quickReference.buyingCommittee: Usually solo decision if embedded, CEO if recruiting or strategic
whenWarm: They ask about your team's technical background
They inquire about the embedded process
They mention specific capacity needs

teamMembers.name: Scott Blevins

icp.title: The Technical Leader Scaling Fast and Breaking Things

connectCriteria: CTO/VP Eng at Series B+ high-growth company
Posts about 'AI strategy,' 'innovation bottleneck,' or 'new products'
Mentions 'board pressure,' 'need to innovate,' or 'can't pull people from core'
Shares specific initiatives they're exploring (AI features, new product lines)
Recently raised funding (have budget, have pressure to show innovation)
engageCriteria: At stable/slow-growth companies (not feeling urgency)
Posts only about team management/culture (not technical innovation)
Works in highly regulated industries (slow decision cycles)
Focus purely on operational efficiency (not innovation-focused)
realQuotes: AI tooling reviews and recommendations.
AI news that actually matters for business.
Evaluating AI ROI — cutting through the hype.
Need to innovate offerings.
Need a team to help expand builders with new products.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [AI strategy]. Most CTOs we work with are getting board pressure to 'do something with AI' but don't want to bet the company on hype. Are you in validation mode or execution mode?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they discuss AI strategy or board pressure

conversationStarters.template: [Name], your post about [new product/innovation] hit home. The classic problem: want to innovate but can't pull people from core product without breaking things. How are you thinking about resourcing?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention innovation bottlenecks

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], curious question - if you could spin up a dedicated 4-person team tomorrow to work ONLY on [innovation project] with zero impact to core engineering, what would you have them build?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: Opening conversation about dedicated innovation teams

contentPillars.title: AI Strategy Without Hype
contentPillars.description: Cut through the noise with real implementation insights
examples: Framework: How to evaluate AI ROI [our decision criteria]
Case study: We built [AI feature] and here's what actually worked
Hot take: Most AI strategies are just press releases
contentPillars.postingTips: Be skeptical of hype. CTOs appreciate realistic takes on AI.

contentPillars.title: Innovation at Scale
contentPillars.description: Show how to innovate without disrupting core
examples: Process: How to run innovation projects without disrupting core engineering
Story: What happened when [company] tried to innovate without dedicated team
Framework: When to build in-house vs. embed a skunkworks team
contentPillars.postingTips: Show the actual org structure and resourcing model.

contentPillars.title: Transparent Experiments
contentPillars.description: Build credibility through honest reporting
examples: Failure story: We bet on [AI approach] and it failed - here's why
Behind-scenes: What our AI implementation process looks like [step-by-step]
Data: AI features that actually moved metrics vs. ones that flopped
contentPillars.postingTips: Share both wins and losses. Data trumps opinions.

engagementBoosters.why: 'We implemented [specific AI use case]' not 'AI is the future'
'AI feature increased [metric] by X%' - CTOs trust data
Follow Shreyas Doshi on product AI, AI Twitter luminaries
'Unpopular opinion: Most AI features add no value'
Scaling CTOs read long-form, 1200+ words is fine

redFlags: Pure AI hype (want 'AI' for press, not real use cases)
No innovation mandate from leadership (won't get budget)
Core product is on fire (all resources on stability)
CEO and CTO misaligned on priorities (political nightmare)
Posts only about cost-cutting or efficiency (not innovation mode)
trustBuilders: Case studies from similar-scale companies (Series B/C)
AI implementation examples with real metrics
Team credentials (senior engineers, proven AI experience)
How you integrate without disrupting core engineering
ROI models (cost vs. value)

quickReference.decisionSpeed: MEDIUM to SLOW (6-12 weeks typical—lots of stakeholders)
quickReference.buyingCommittee: CEO (strategic), CFO (budget), VP Eng (integration), sometimes board
whenWarm: They ask about specific AI implementations
They share innovation roadmap details
They mention board or investor pressure

teamMembers.name: Sonya Mead

icp.title: The Talent Leader Drowning in Sourcing

connectCriteria: Director of HR/People at growth-stage company
Posts about 'hiring challenges,' 'can't find qualified candidates,' or 'time to fill'
Mentions 'engineers/designers/technical roles' specifically (your specialty)
Shares open roles or 'we're hiring' posts (actively recruiting)
Talks about 'founders spending time recruiting' or 'makers doing HR work'
engageCriteria: Posts only about HR compliance/benefits (not recruiting)
Works at huge enterprises (different recruiting model)
Solo HR at tiny startup (might not have budget yet)
Focus on employer branding/culture (not urgent hiring)
realQuotes: Hiring without slowing down your builders.
Makers spending time sourcing talent instead of moving product forward.
Needing to hire a lot over time.
No time to sift through applicants.
Building a recruiting engine from scratch.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [hiring challenge]. Quick question - how much time are your founders/engineers spending on recruiting vs. actually building product? That ratio is usually eye-opening.
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about hiring or capacity issues

conversationStarters.template: [Name], your post about [application volume] resonated. Most HR leaders we work with are drowning in unqualified applicants. Are you pre-screening technical skills before they hit your founders' calendars?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they mention quality or volume challenges

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], curious - when you think about your hiring goals, what worries you more: finding candidates or making sure they actually stick around? We've got 90% voluntary retention on our placements because [reason].
conversationStarters.whenToUse: Opening conversation about quality of hire

contentPillars.title: Recruiting for Lean Teams
contentPillars.description: Help founders and small HR teams hire without slowing down
examples: Framework: How to hire without slowing down your builders [step-by-step]
Data: The real cost of founders doing recruiting [calculate opportunity cost]
Case study: How [company] filled 5 roles in 8 weeks without internal recruiting team
contentPillars.postingTips: Emphasize time savings. Show actual hours saved.

contentPillars.title: Technical Recruiting Reality
contentPillars.description: Position as experts in tech hiring
examples: Guide: How to screen technical candidates when you're not technical
Hot take: Stop requiring 5 years of React experience for mid-level roles
Behind-scenes: What our technical vetting process actually looks like
contentPillars.postingTips: Be opinionated about hiring practices. Show expertise.

contentPillars.title: Quality Over Volume
contentPillars.description: Address the pain of unqualified applicants
examples: Story: Why 200 applications doesn't mean 200 candidates
Framework: How to identify quality candidates in first 30 seconds [checklist]
Data: Our 90% retention rate and why it matters
contentPillars.postingTips: Lead with retention stat. It's your differentiator.

engagementBoosters.why: 'Not your typical job post: [creative description]'
'What technical candidates actually care about in 2026'
SHRM, HR Tech, Talent Acquisition groups
'What's your biggest recruiting bottleneck? [sourcing/screening/offers/onboarding]'
'What our intake call with hiring managers looks like'

redFlags: Hiring freeze or recent layoffs (not actively recruiting)
Only hiring for non-technical roles (not your specialty)
Toxic culture signals (high Glassdoor complaints, public drama)
Unrealistic expectations ('need senior engineers for $60k')
Posts only about HR compliance/benefits (not recruiting-focused)
trustBuilders: Sample candidates in their tech stack/industry
Placement success rate (90% retention stat)
Process explanation (how do you source/screen?)
Cost structure (contingency? Retainer?)
Reference calls with other founders/HR leaders

quickReference.buyingCommittee: Usually solo decision if HR leader, CEO if founder-led
whenWarm: They've shared specific open roles
They mention time spent on recruiting
They've had bad experiences with recruiters
